The limit of 5 Elastic IP addresses per region for EC2 instances is a soft limit. Soft limits can be increased or raised by submitting a request to AWS support. If you need more than 5 Elastic IP addresses for your EC2 instances in a specific region, you can contact AWS support and request a limit increase.

Elasticity, in the context of cloud computing and services like AWS Elastic Beanstalk, refers to the ability to automatically and dynamically adjust the allocated resources (such as compute, storage, and networking) based on the changing demands of the application or workload. With elasticity, your infrastructure can scale in (reduce resources) or scale out (increase resources) as needed to handle fluctuations in traffic, workload, or demand. This helps ensure optimal performance, cost efficiency, and responsiveness to varying levels of usage.

questions.answer_description:
An Auto Scaling group contains a collection of EC2 instances that share similar characteristics and are treated as a logical grouping for the purposes of instance scaling and management.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/latest/userguide/AutoScalingGroup.html
questions.question_text: What is an Auto Scaling group?

choices.A: It is a group of ELBs that are used to add instances from various regions.
choices.D: It is a group of launch configurations for Elastic load balancers in the same region.
choices.C: It is a collection of EC2 instance launch parameters with different characteristics for scaling and management.
choices.B: It is a logical grouping of EC2 instances that share similar characteristics for scaling and man-agement.

discussion.content: B. It is a logical grouping of EC2 instances that share similar characteristics for scaling and man-agement.
